content.question: What charge does <math alttext="A l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Al</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> typically have in ionic compounds, and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="positive 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because in the ground state it has one unpaired electron.

<math alttext="positive 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it has two electrons in the <math alttext="2 s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> subshell.
<math alttext="positive 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it has three valence electrons.
<math alttext="positive 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it is in the fourth row of the periodic table.

content.answer: <math alttext="positive 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it has three valence electrons.
